description: From Latin trītus "worn out," a form of the verb terō (“I wear away, wear out”).

entries.meaning: Often in reference to a word or phrase: used so many times that it is commonplace, or no longer interesting or effective; worn out, hackneyed.
examples: It is a trite saying in a young country that anyone starting out in life with the determination to become wealthy will have his wish gratified.

entries.meaning: (law) So well established as to be beyond debate: trite law.
examples: It is trite to say that the mere fact that a decision does not favour the applicant or that the applicant disagrees with the decision does not establish that the decision is tainted with bias.

entries.meaning: A denomination of coinage in ancient Greece equivalent to one third of a stater.
Trite, a genus of spiders, found in Australia, New Zealand and Oceania, of the family Salticidae.
